sections.text: Camila Vega: Hi Hassan—good to see you again. Last time you mentioned you liked the idea of tightening follow-up after discovery and getting more consistency across the team without replacing Salesforce. Today I’d love to show you how Sales_Accelerator would do that in practice and what it would take to roll it out at Indigoriver Ventures. Sound good?
Hassan Rahman: Yep, that works. We’ve been talking internally, and there’s interest—especially if it helps reps stay on top of deals without adding admin work.

Camila Vega: Perfect. I’ll focus on two things: the follow-up workflow after discovery, and the warning alerts that keep deals from going dark. Both sit on top of your CRM and pull in the fit and positioning blocks you already have in Customer_Analyzer—so you’re not redoing ICP work.
Hassan Rahman: Okay. The “sit on top” part is important. We don’t want another system of record.

Camila Vega: Exactly. Salesforce remains the system of record. Sales_Accelerator is more like an execution layer: it watches what’s happening in the opportunity, and then it recommends the next best actions. Let me start with the follow-up use case you called out.
Hassan Rahman: Sure.

Camila Vega: After discovery, the AE clicks “Generate follow-up.” Sales_Accelerator drafts a recap email based on call notes and the opportunity fields—then it suggests two tailored proof points from the approved positioning library that came from Customer_Analyzer. So instead of every rep freelancing, they’re pulling from the same vetted language, but it still feels customized to that account’s priorities.
Hassan Rahman: That’s compelling. Our biggest gap is inconsistency—some AEs do great recaps and next steps, others don’t.

Camila Vega: Right—and then the second piece in that same flow is it creates a mutual action plan. Not a generic checklist—an actual plan with due dates, owners, and stakeholders. It also nudges reps to multi-thread by suggesting roles you’re missing—like procurement, IT/security, or an executive sponsor—based on deal type and what’s typical for your wins.
Hassan Rahman: I like that. We’ve lost deals because we were single-threaded and didn’t know until it was too late.

Camila Vega: That’s a great segue into the warning alerts feature. Sales_Accelerator continuously scans for risk signals: inactivity—like no touches in X days—stage aging beyond benchmarks, no upcoming meeting on the calendar, champion risk when you’re single-threaded, pricing or terms risk if certain keywords show up, and forecast risk when a commit deal starts weakening.
Hassan Rahman: When you say “keywords,” do you mean it’s reading our notes?

Camila Vega: It can, yes—based on what you allow. Some customers start with the safer signals first: stage aging, inactivity, and “no upcoming meeting.” Then they add deeper signals like competitive mentions in notes once they’re comfortable. Alerts can route to Slack, email, and into Salesforce, and each alert comes with a recommended remediation action.
Hassan Rahman: That remediation part matters. We don’t need another notification flood.

Camila Vega: Totally. The goal is “alert plus what to do next.” So if a deal has no upcoming meeting, the recommendation might be “propose two times for next step and include mutual action plan link.” If it’s champion risk, it might be “schedule exec alignment” or “add stakeholder from finance/security.” And we can tune thresholds so you only see alerts that actually correlate with slippage for your team.
Hassan Rahman: My concern is explainability. Reps will push back if the system says “this is at risk” and they can’t see why.

Camila Vega: That’s the most common—and most valid—concern. We handle it two ways. First, every alert shows its drivers in plain language: “No activity in 9 days,” “Stage age 2.3x benchmark,” “Single-threaded: only one contact engaged,” “No meeting scheduled in next 14 days.” Second, you can click into an “evidence view” that shows the timeline of touches, meetings, and stage changes that led to that risk flag. The point is to make it inspectable, not magical.
Hassan Rahman: That helps. If a manager can point to concrete signals, adoption is easier.

Camila Vega: Exactly—and for managers, there’s also a “high-fit but at-risk” lens. Because we pull Customer_Analyzer fit scores, you can prioritize intervention where it matters most. So instead of chasing every red flag, you focus on the deals that are both valuable and slipping.
Hassan Rahman: That’s interesting. We have limited leadership bandwidth, so we need triage.
Camila Vega: Right. Now, quick check—what’s your current process when a deal starts to stall? Is it mostly manager gut feel, or do you have any standardized triggers?
Hassan Rahman: It’s mostly gut feel, plus some dashboards. But dashboards don’t tell you what to do. Reps also don’t always update fields on time, so the data’s imperfect.

Camila Vega: Understood. We’re not going to pretend we can fix every hygiene issue overnight, but we can reduce dependence on perfect fields by using activity signals—meetings, emails, tasks, notes—plus what’s in the CRM. And for the parts that do require structured data, we can start small with two or three signals you trust, prove value, and expand.
Hassan Rahman: Makes sense. Another concern: will reps feel like this is “big brother”?

Camila Vega: We position it as “copilot, not police.” Practically, that means reps get benefits immediately—draft recap emails, suggested proof points, mutual action plans—so it’s not just oversight. And alerts aren’t just for managers; they’re primarily for reps to protect their own pipeline. Managers can have a view, but we can tune who gets what.
Hassan Rahman: Good. If reps get time back, they’ll be more open.

Camila Vega: Exactly. Let’s talk about your rollout. You mentioned last time you have about 18 AEs and 6 SDRs, and you’re forecasting more hires this year. What would success look like 60 days after implementation?
Hassan Rahman: Two things: fewer deals slipping silently, and better post-discovery follow-up consistency. If we can see that in metrics, we can expand.

Camila Vega: Great. Then I’d propose a pilot with, say, 6 AEs across two teams. We’ll configure: (1) the discovery follow-up generator—recap email plus proof points plus mutual action plan, and (2) three warning alerts to start: inactivity, no upcoming meeting, and single-thread/champion risk. We’ll measure adoption—like follow-up generated rate—and outcomes like stage progression velocity and slip rate on commits.
Hassan Rahman: What about setup time? Sales ops bandwidth is tight.

Camila Vega: For the pilot, we keep it light: connect Salesforce, connect your calendar, connect Customer_Analyzer, and agree on the initial benchmarks for stage aging. We’ll do most of the configuration with one sales ops point person for a couple hours a week for two to three weeks. After that it’s mostly feedback and tuning.
Hassan Rahman: That’s reasonable. And the explainability piece—can we show reps “why this proof point was suggested” too?

Camila Vega: Yes. On the proof points, it will cite the underlying positioning block and what account signals triggered it—like industry, priorities from the notes, and fit attributes from Customer_Analyzer. Reps can swap suggestions, but they’ll always see the rationale, so it builds trust.
Hassan Rahman: Okay. I’m leaning toward moving forward. What would you need from me to get a pilot approved?

Camila Vega: Two things: a pilot sponsor—you—and one sales ops contact for the integration and field mapping. If you’re comfortable, I’ll send a one-page pilot plan today with scope, success metrics, and timeline. Then we can do a 30-minute working session early next week to confirm the alert thresholds and the follow-up templates. After that, we can have the pilot live within about three weeks.
Hassan Rahman: Send the one-pager. I can pull in our sales ops lead—Mina—if you give me a heads up on what you need from her.

Camila Vega: Perfect. I’ll outline exactly what Mina would do and what we handle. Last question: assuming the pilot hits the metrics, are you thinking expand to the full AE org first, or AE plus SDR together?
Hassan Rahman: Probably AEs first, then SDRs. The follow-up and risk alerts feel more AE-centric initially.
Camila Vega: Agreed. I’ll frame the expansion path that way. I’ll send the pilot plan within the hour—can we tentatively hold Tuesday at 11am for the working session?
Hassan Rahman: Tuesday at 11 works. Send the invite and the doc, and I’ll review before then.
Camila Vega: Will do. Thanks Hassan—this is a good fit for what you described: consistency after discovery and fewer surprise slips. I’ll follow up shortly with the details.
Hassan Rahman: Sounds good. Talk Tuesday.
